newsitem.title: BOLIVIA: Bolivia may cancel Sustainable Development summit.
newsitem.headline: Bolivia may cancel Sustainable Development summit.

text.p: Bolivia may have to cancel a regional development summit in December because of disagreement between the United States and Latin America on the focus of the talks, a government minister was quoted on Tuesday as saying.
"If there is agreement on the basic agenda, the summit goes ahead; if not, it won't, that's quite clear," Foreign Minister Antonio Aranibar said in comments reported by the Bolivian press.

La Razon newspaper said the United States and some other countries believed the talks should focus exclusively on the environment, while most Latin American nations wanted a broader discussion of sustainable economic and social development.

Thirty-four Western Hemisphere nations are due to attend the summit in the eastern Bolivian city of Santa Cruz on December 7-8, a result of the Summit of the Americas held in Miami in December 1994. Cuba has not been invited.
"For any meeting of this kind there has to be consensus. It is not up to Bolivia to insist on a summit taking place, but up to all these countries together," said the minister.
He said Bolivian President Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada had made it "very clear that the fight against poverty is an essential part of the concept of sustainable development."
And Congressman Miguel Uriosta, acting head of the leftist Free Bolivia Movement to which Aranibar belongs, said Monday: "If poverty is not included, there will be no summit."
But Aranibar said the issue might be resolved at a meeting of the permanent council of the Organisation of American States due to take place in Washington this week.
